pullRequest.title: Implement JarProcessor to determine jar type.
pullRequest.bodyText:
Part 1 of #2796.
Determine whether the jar is a Spring Boot fat jar or regular jar, given the path to the jar file. Note that this method doesn't take into account, Spring Boot thin jars or other types of fat jars yet. If the jar is not a Spring Boot jar then it is considered a regular jar.
This implementation will use Truth (https://truth.dev/) for testing.

commit.message: Implement JarProcessor to determine jar type and use Truth for tests

nodes.bodyText: May need to add more logic to verify that the jar is in fact a regular jar, otherwise throw an exception saying that non-springboot fat jars are not supported.

See the + * License for the specific language governing permissions and limitations under + * the License. + */ + +package com.google.cloud.tools.jib.cli.jar; + +import java.io.IOException; +import java.nio.file.Path; +import java.util.jar.JarFile; + +public class JarProcessor { + + /** + * Jar Type. + * + *
    + *
  • {@code REGULAR} a regular jar. + *
  • {@code SPRINGBOOT} a springboot fat jar. * + *
+ */ + public enum JarType { + REGULAR, + SPRINGBOOT; + } + + /** + * Determines whether the jar is a spring-boot or regular jar, given a path to the jar. + * + * @param jarPath path to the jar. + * @return the jar type. + * @throws IOException if I/O error occurs when opening the file. + */ + public static JarType determineJarType(Path jarPath) throws IOException { + JarFile jarFile = new JarFile(jarPath.toString()); + if (jarFile.getEntry("BOOT-INF") != null) { + return JarType.SPRINGBOOT; + } + return JarType.REGULAR;

nodes.bodyText:
Suggested change
        
          
    

        
      
    
    
      
          
            
               *   <li>{@code SPRINGBOOT} a springboot fat jar. *
          
          
            
               *   <li>{@code SPRING_BOOT} a springboot fat jar.

commit.message: refine naming and include suggested changes
Merge branch 'cli-determine-jar-type' of github.com:GoogleContainerTools/jib into cli-determine-jar-type

nodes.bodyText: I think STANDARD is probably the more standard term?

commit.message: Rename regular to standard and use small spring boot jar for testing
